sen.j: 足利 義教（あしかが よしのり、応永元年6月14日（1394年7月12日） - 嘉吉元年6月24日（1441年7月12日）は、室町幕府第6代征夷大将軍（将軍職1428-1441年）。
sen.e: Yoshinori ASHIKAGA (July 12, 1394 - July 12, 1441) was the 6th Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo) of the Muromachi shogunate (shogunship from 1428 to 1441).
Yoshinori ASHIKAGA (July 12, 1394 - July 12, 1441) was the 6th Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo) of the Muromachi shogunate (shogunship from 1428 to 1441).
Yoshinori ASHIKAGA (July 20, 1394 - July 21, 1441) was the 6th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi shogunate (shogunship from 1428 to 1441).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変換Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo)→Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")に変更しました。

sen.j: 3代将軍足利義満の3男。
sen.e: He was the third son of the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.
He was the third son of the third shogun, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.
He was the third son of the third shogun, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 母は安芸法眼の娘藤原慶子（ふじわらのよしこ）で4代将軍足利義持の同母弟。
sen.e: His mother was FUJIWARA no Yoshiko, a daughter of Hogan AKI, and he was a younger brother of the fourth shogun Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA whose mother also was FUJIWARA no Yoshiko.
His mother was FUJIWARA no Yoshiko, a daughter of Hogan AKI, and he was a younger brother of the fourth shogun Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: Deleted " whose mother also was FUJIWARA no Yoshiko" - although this is in the Japanese, I think most English speakers would assume their mother was the same
sen.e: His mother was FUJIWARA no Yoshiko, a daughter of Hogan AKI, and he was a younger brother of the fourth shogun Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 当初出家しており「義円」と呼ばれていたが、家督を継ぐにあたり還俗し「義宣（よしのぶ）」と称したものの、「世を偲ぶ」につながることから改名を決意し朝廷から贈られた「義敏」という名を蹴って「義教」と名乗った。
sen.e: He had been retired into the priesthood and was called 'Gien,' but he named himself 'Yoshinobu' as he returned to secular life to succeed to the headship of his house; however, he decided to change his name yet again as the sound of his name was reminiscent of 'thinking back in time' and called himself 'Yoshinori' rejecting the name 'Yoshitoshi' that the Imperial court granted him.

He had entered the priesthood, taking the name 'Gien,' but upon returning to secular life to succeed to the headship of his family, he named himself 'Yoshinobu', though as this name sounded similar to 'mourning the past', he called himself 'Yoshinori', rejecting the name 'Yoshitoshi' that the Imperial court granted him.
sen.cmt: Reworded sentence to make less wordy.Changed translation of "世を偲ぶ" - 偲ぶ carries implications of remembering the dead
sen.e: He had entered the priesthood, taking the name 'Gien,' but upon returning to secular life to succeed to the headship of his family, he named himself 'Yoshinobu,' althouth as this name sounded similar to 'mourning the past,' he called himself 'Yoshinori,' rejecting the name 'Yoshitoshi' that the Imperial Court granted him.

sen.j: 官位は従一位左大臣、贈太政大臣。
sen.e: His official rank was the Minister of the Left at the Junior First Court Rank and was raised to the Grand Minister after his death.
His official rank was the Minister of the Left at the Junior First Court Rank and he was posthumously promoted to Chief Minister.
sen.cmt: "was raised to the Grand Minister after his death"→"he was posthumously promoted to Chief Minister"
sen.e: His official rank was the Juichii-sadaijin (minister of the left at the Junior First Rank) and he was posthumously promoted to Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state).
sen.cmt: 従一位左大臣→Juichii-sadaijin (minister of the left at the Junior First Rank)太政大臣→Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state)

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: His Life
Life
Biography

sen.j: 足利幕府将軍の家督相続者以外の子として、慣例により仏門に入って「義円」と名乗り青蓮院門跡にあった。
sen.e: As he was not a successor of the shogun family of the Ashikaga shogunate government, according to the custom, he entered the Buddhist priesthood, called himself 'Gien,' and resided at the Shoren-In Monseki Temple.
As he was not in line to inherit the headship of the family, he followed tradition and entered the Buddhist priesthood, taking the name 'Gien,' and residing at Shoren-In Monzeki Temple.
sen.cmt: "a successor of the shogun family of the Ashikaga shogunate government"→"in line to inherit the headship of the family" "according to the custom"→"followed tradition and" and moved"called himself"→"taking the name""resided"→"residing"Deleted "the""Monseki"→"Monzeki"
sen.e: As he was not in line to inherit the headship of the family, he followed tradition and entered the Buddhist priesthood, taking the name 'Gien,' and residing at Shoren-in Monzeki Temple.

sen.j: その後百五十三代天台座主となり、『天台開闢以来の逸材』と呼ばれ将来を嘱望されていた。
sen.e: He then became the 153rd priest of the Tendai sect, was called 'the most talented person in the history of the Tendai sect,' and was regarded as a promising priest.
He then became the 153rd head priest of the Tendai sect, was called 'the most talented person in the history of the Tendai sect,' and was regarded as having a promising future.
sen.cmt: Added "head""a promising priest"→"having a promising future"
sen.e: He then became the one hundred fifty-third head priest of the Tendai sect, was called 'the most talented person in the history of the Tendai sect,' and was regarded as having a promising future.

sen.j: このまま義教は高僧として生涯を終えるはずであったが、1425年（応永32年）、兄で4代将軍足利義持の子である5代将軍足利義量が急逝し、義持も1428年（正長元年）に後継者を決めないまま没したため、管領畠山満家の発案によって、石清水八幡宮で行われたくじ引きで複数の候補者（兄弟の梶井義承・大覚寺義昭・虎山永隆・義円）の中から将軍に選ばれることになった。
sen.e: He planned to live his life as a high priest, but after the 5th shogun Yoshikazu ASHIKAGA, who was his older brother as well as the son of the 4th shogun Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA, died suddenly in 1425, and Yoshimochi died in 1428 without deciding his heir, a shogunal deputy Mitsuie HATAKEYAMA suggested a plan that the next shogun would be selected from the candidates (Gisho KAJII, Gisho DAIKAKUJI, Eiryu KOZAN, and Gien) by a drawing at the Iwahimizu Hachimangu shrine.

He planned to live his life as a high priest, but after the 5th shogun, Yoshikazu ASHIKAGA, the son of his older brother, the 4th Shogun, Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA, died suddenly in 1425, and Yoshimochi died in 1428 without deciding his heir, the Kanrei (shogunal deputy), Mitsuie HATAKEYAMA, suggested a plan that the next shogun should be selected from the candidates (Gisho KAJII, Gisho DAIKAKUJI, Eiryu KOZAN, and Gien) by a lottery at Iwahimizu Hachimangu Shrine.
sen.cmt: "his older brother as well as the son of the 4th shogun"→"the son of his older brother, the 4th Shogun,""a shogunal deputy"→"the Kanrei (shogunal deputy)""would"→"should""drawing"→"lottery"Deleted "the"Capitalized 's'
sen.e: He planned to live his life as a high priest, but after the 5th shogun, Yoshikazu ASHIKAGA, the son of his older brother, the 4th Shogun, Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA, died suddenly in 1425, and Yoshimochi died in 1428 without deciding his heir, the Kanrei (shogunal deputy), Mitsuie HATAKEYAMA, suggested a plan that the next shogun should be selected from the candidates (Gisho KAJII, Gisho DAIKAKUJI, Eiryu KOZAN, and Gien) by a lottery at Iwahimizu Hachimangu Shrine.

sen.j: くじ引きに関しては、神を感じていた中世のことだから公正であったとする説、満済らが事前に仕組んだ不正であるとする説もある。
sen.e: Some say that the drawing was fair because it took place in the Middle Ages in which people believed in God while some say that the drawing was unfair and set up by Mansai.
Some say that the lottery was fair because it took place in the Middle Ages, when people believed in the gods, while some say it was unfair and set up by Mansai.
sen.cmt: "drawing"→"lottery""in which people believed in God"→", when people believed in the gods""that the drawing"→"it"
sen.e: Some say that the lottery was fair because it took place in the Middle Ages, when people believed in the gods, while some say it was unfair and set up by Mansai.

sen.j: このことから、6代将軍に就任した義教は、籤引き将軍と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Yoshinori as a result became the 6th shogun and was called a drawn shogun.
As a result, Yoshinori was selected as the 6th shogun, becoming known as the 'lottery shogun'.
sen.cmt: Moved "as a result""became""→"was selected"" and was called a drawn shogun"→", becoming known as the 'lottery shogun'"
sen.e: As a result, Yoshinori was selected as the 6th shogun, becoming known as the 'lottery shogun.'

sen.j: だがすぐには義教は承知せず、就任の際には斯波氏、畠山氏、細川氏から「将軍を抜きに勝手なことをしない」と証文をとった。
sen.e: Yoshinori however did not accept the result for a while and, when he became shogun at the end, he made the Shiba, Hatakeyama and Hosokawa families put in signed writing that 'they would always consult with the shogun before taking any actions.'

Yoshinori, however, did not accept the result for a while and when he finally became Shogun, he made the Shiba, Hatakeyama and Hosokawa families sign a statement that 'they would always consult with the shogun before taking any actions.'
sen.cmt: Added commas"became shogun at the end"→"when he finally became Shogun" "put in signed writing"→"sign a statement"
sen.e: Yoshinori, however, did not accept the result for a while and when he finally became Shogun, he made the Shiba, Hatakeyama and Hosokawa families sign a statement that 'they would always consult with the shogun before taking any actions.'

tit.e: Recovery of the Power of the Shogunate Government

sen.j: 将軍就任を果たした義教の目標は、失墜した幕府権威の復興と将軍親政の復活であった。
sen.e: The goals of Yoshinori who was now a shogun were recovery of the power of the shogunate government that had been lost and resurgence of direct governance by shogun.
Once Yoshinori was made Shogun, his goals became the recovery of the shogunate's power and the restoration of direct rule by the Shogun.
Once Yoshinori was made Shogun, his goals became the recovery of the shogunate's power and the restoration of direct rule by the Shogun.

sen.j: 施策の手本は父足利義満に求めたと思われ、手始めに1428年の称光天皇死後の皇位継承問題を手がける。
sen.e: It is believed that he requested his father Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA to provide him example measures, and to start with, Yoshinori addressed the issue of succession to the throne that was brought up after the death of Emperor Shoko in 1428.

It is believed that he asked his father, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, to provide him with example policies, and to start with, Yoshinori addressed the issue of succession to the throne that arose after the death of Emperor Shoko in 1428.
sen.cmt: "requested"→"asked" - "requested" is OK but it sounds a little unnatural hereAdded commas and "with""measures"→"policies" "was brought up"→"arose"
sen.e: It is believed that he asked his father, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, to provide him with example policies, and to start with, Yoshinori addressed the issue of succession to the throne that arose after the death of Emperor Shoko in 1428.

sen.j: 後花園天皇の新続古今和歌集は義教の執奏によるものである。
sen.e: Compilation of the New Continued Collection from Ancient and Modern Times was Yoshinori's idea and was ordered by Emperor GoHanazono.
The Shinshokukokin-wakashu (New Compilation of Ancient and Modern Times Continued), an anthology of waka poetry ordered by Emperor Go-Hanazono, was Yoshinori's idea.
sen.cmt: Not sure if the 新続古今和歌集 has an official English name so added Japanese name and brief explanation, as well as changing the translation of the title slightly.
sen.e: The Shinshokukokin Wakashu (New Compilation of Ancient and Modern Times Continued), an anthology of waka poetry ordered by Emperor Gohanazono, was Yoshinori's idea.
sen.cmt: 後花園天皇→Emperor GoHanazono‘→'-w→-削除, W

sen.j: 三宝院満済を政治顧問に儀礼の形式や訴訟手続きなどを義満時代のものを復活させ、参加者の身分・家柄が固定化された評定衆・引付に代わって、自らが主宰して参加者を指名する御前沙汰を協議機関とすることで管領の権限抑制策を打ち出した。
sen.e: He established a policy to restrict the extent of shogunal deputy power by appointing Mansai SAMPOIN to be a political adviser so that ceremonial styles and judicial proceedings that were used during the time of Yoshimitsu would be restored, and also by adopting the 'gozensata' system as a consultative organization that he hosted and appointed participants for in order to replace the 'hyojyoshu' consultative board and 'hitsuke' judicial board that accepted individuals of only certain positions or families as participants.

He established a policy to restrict the Kanrei's power by appointing Mansai SAMPOIN as a political adviser so that ceremonial styles and judicial proceedings that were used during the time of Yoshimitsu would be restored, and also by replacing the 'hyojyoshu' consultative board and 'hitsuke' judicial board, which accepted individuals of only certain positions or families as participants, with the 'gozensata' advisory council, that he chaired and whose members were chosen by him.
sen.cmt: Deleted "extent of""shogunal deputy"→"the Kanrei's" "to be"→"as" Changed word order and reworded "nd half of sentence
sen.e: He established a policy to restrict the Kanrei's power by appointing Mansai SANPOIN as a political adviser so that ceremonial styles and judicial proceedings that were used during the time of Yoshimitsu would be restored, and also by replacing the 'hyojyoshu' consultative board and 'hikitsuke' judicial board, which accepted individuals of only certain positions or families as participants, with the 'gozensata' advisory council, that he chaired and whose members were chosen by him.

sen.j: そして義持の代から中断していた勘合貿易を再開させて財政政策を見直すなど、幕府権力の強化につとめた。
sen.e: He then restarted the tally trade that was suspended since the Yoshimochi generation and reviewed the financial policy in order to reinforce the government power.
He then restarted the tally trade with China that had been suspended since Yoshimochi's time and reviewed financial policy in order to reinforce the government's power.
sen.cmt: Added with "China" for clarity"was"→"had been" "the Yoshimochi generation"→"Yoshimochi's time" Deleted "the"
sen.e: He then restarted the tally trade with China that had been suspended since Yoshimochi's time and reviewed financial policy in order to reinforce the government's power.

sen.j: また彼は政教分離を進め、中央集権体制を確立すべく行動していく。
sen.e: He also encouraged separation of government and religion and took actions to establish the centralized administrative system.
He also encouraged separation of government and religion and took measures to establish a centralized administrative system.
He also encouraged separation of government and religion and took measures to establish a centralized administrative system.

sen.j: 軍事力についても、将軍直轄の奉公衆の整備など軍制改革を行って力を得る。
sen.e: In the field of military affairs, too, he gained power by carrying out a military system reform such as development of a guard force under the shogun's direct control.
He also increased his control of the military by carrying out reforms such as the development of the Hokoshu, vassals under the shogun's direct control.
He also increased his control of the military by carrying out reforms such as the development of the Hokoshu (a military post in Muromachi Shogunate), vassals under the shogun's direct control.

sen.j: そして鎌倉公方足利持氏が、正長から永享に改元したにも拘らず正長の年号を使い続け、また鎌倉五山の住職を勝手に決定するなどの専横を口実とし討伐を試みる。
sen.e: He then attempted to subjugate Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, a Kamakura Kubo, using the excuses that ASHIKAGA kept using the era name Shocho even after it had been changed from Shocho to Eikyo, and that ASHIKAGA appointed at his discretion the head priests for the Five Official Temples of Kamakura.

He then attempted to subjugate Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the Kamakura Kubo, using the excuses that ASHIKAGA kept using the era name Shocho even after it had been changed from Shocho to Eikyo, and that ASHIKAGA appointed at his discretion the head priests for the Five Official Temples of Kamakura.

He then attempted to subjugate Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the Kamakura Kubo, using the excuses that Ashikaga kept using the era name Shocho even after it had been changed from Shocho to Eikyo, and that Ashikaga appointed at his discretion the head priests for the Five Official Temples of Kamakura.

sen.j: これは反対に遭い断念するが、代わりに大内盛見に九州征伐を命じた。
sen.e: He faced opposition however and abandoned the plan, instead ordering Morimi OUCHI to subjugate the Kyushu area.
He faced opposition however and abandoned the plan, instead ordering Morimi OUCHI to subjugate the Kyushu area.
He faced opposition however and abandoned the plan, instead ordering Morimi OUCHI to subjugate the Kyushu area.

sen.j: 盛見は戦死したが跡を継いだ甥の大内持世が山名氏の手を借りて渋川氏や少弐氏・大友氏を撃破、腹心となった持世を九州探題とし九州を支配下に置いた。
sen.e: Morimi was killed in the battle, but Mochiyo OUCHI took over the leadership and with the help of the Yamana family defeated the Shoni and Otomo families, and had the Kyushu area under control of the newly established Kyushu military branch headed by Mochiyo who was considered to be trustworthy.

Morimi was killed in the battle but his nephew, Mochiyo OUCHI, took over the leadership and, with the help of the Yamana family, defeated the Shibukawa Clan and the Shoni and Otomo Clans, with Mochiyo, who was trusted by Yoshinori, being made Commissioner of Kyushu.
sen.cmt: Added "his nephew" as in JapaneseAdded "Shibukawa Clan""families""Clans""and had the Kyushu area under control of the newly established Kyushu military branch headed by Mochiyo who was considered to be trustworthy"→"with Mochiyo, who was trusted by Yoshinori, being made Commissioner of Kyushu"
sen.e: Morimi was killed in the battle but his nephew, Mochiyo OUCHI, took over the leadership and, with the help of the Yamana family, defeated the Shibukawa Clan and the Shoni and Otomo Clans, with Mochiyo, who was trusted by Yoshinori, being made Commissioner of Kyushu.

tit.e: Power Struggle Against the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple
tit.cmt: この項における「比叡山」は「比叡山延暦寺」(Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple)を意味していると考え、そのように訳出いたしました。
tit.e: Power Struggle Against Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple
Power Struggle Against Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple

sen.j: もともと天台座主であった義教は還俗後すぐに弟の義承を天台座主に任じ、比叡山勢力の取り込みを図った。
sen.e: Yoshinori, who used to be the priest of the Tendai sect, appointed his own younger brother Gisho to the same position immediately after returning to secular life in order to win over the power of the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple.

In order to control the power of Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, Yoshinori, who had been the head priest of the Tendai sect, appointed his own younger brother, Gisho, to the same position immediately after returning to secular life.
sen.cmt: Moved "in order to win over the power of the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple""win over"→"control"Deleted "the""used to be"→"had been"Added "head"
sen.e: In order to control the power of Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, Yoshinori, who had been the head priest of the Tendai sect, appointed his own younger brother, Gisho, to the same position immediately after returning to secular life.

sen.j: また、満済をはじめ多くの僧を顧問として宗教勢力を懐柔、掌握しようと試みた。
sen.e: He also used many priests such as Mansai as advisers in an attempt to conciliate with and seize the religionist power.
He also used many priests such as Mansai as advisers in an attempt to appease and take control of the religious influence.
He also used many priests such as Mansai as advisers in an attempt to appease and take control of the religious influence.

sen.j: ところが1433年（永享5年）に比叡山が幕府に十二か条からなる要求を行い、義教は応じたものの、それにもかかわらず僧兵が暴動を起こすに至って激怒し自ら兵を率いて比叡山を攻撃、比叡山側は降伏して一旦は停戦するものの翌年には足利持氏の依頼で義教を比叡山が呪詛しているとの報を受けるに及んで再び出兵、比叡山の高僧を数人斬首するに至り、やがて 1435年（永享7年）2月には比叡山僧侶を焼身自殺に追い込んだ。
sen.e: In 1433, however, the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple issued 12 requests to the government and Yoshinori once accepted them, but being outraged by the fact that armed priests raised a riot even after his acceptance of the requests, he led his army to attack the temple and the temple surrendered and there was a cease fire; however, in the following year, Yoshinori received a report that the temple was cursing him by request from Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, and this triggered him to send troops again, beheaded high priests of the temple, and in February 1435, he drove Buddhist monks of the temple to immolate themselves.

In 1433, Yoshinori accepted 12 conditions issued by Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple but, outraged when monks nonetheless started rioting, led his army in an attack on the temple, forcing it to surrender and accept a ceasefire; however, the following year, Yoshinori received a report from Mochiuji ASHIKAGA that the temple was placing a curse on him, leading him to again send troops and behead several high priests, and in February 1435, the temple's cornered monks immolated themselves.
sen.cmt: Reworded sentence to make it clearer and less wordy but I think it would be better to split it into two
sen.e: In 1433, Yoshinori accepted 12 conditions issued by Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple but, outraged when monks nonetheless started rioting, led his army in an attack on the temple, forcing it to surrender and accept a ceasefire; however, the following year, Yoshinori received a report from Mochiuji ASHIKAGA that the temple was placing a curse on him, leading him to again send troops and behead several high priests, and in March 1435, the temple's cornered monks immolated themselves.

sen.j: これにより最澄以来600年の歴史を誇る根本中堂は灰塵に帰した。
sen.e: As a result, the Konpon-chudo with 600 years of history since its establishment by Saicho burned to ashes.
As a result, the Konpon-chudo Main Hall, built 600 years previously by Saicho, was burned to ashes.
sen.cmt: "with 600 years of history since its establishment by Saicho"→"Main Hall, built 600 years previously by Saicho,"
sen.e: As a result, the Konpon-chudo Main Hall, built 600 years previously by Saicho, was burned to ashes.

sen.j: そして比叡山について噂する者を斬罪に処すとした。
sen.e: He then announced that those who talked about the temple would be punished by decapitation.
He then announced that those who talked about the temple would be punished by decapitation.
He then announced that those who talked about the temple would be punished by decapitation.

sen.j: これにより最大宗教勢力の比叡山は室町幕府に屈したのである。
sen.e: The Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, the largest religionist power in Japan, finally gave in to the Muromachi shogunate government.
The Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, the largest religious power in Japan, finally gave in to the Muromachi shogunate government.
The Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, the largest religious power in Japan, finally gave in to the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 室町幕府→Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

sen.j: また興福寺への武力介入などにより、仏教勢力の政治介入の駆逐につとめた。
sen.e: Also, through military intervention to the Kofuku-ji Temple, Yoshinori tried to drive out political intervention by the Buddhist power.
Also, with an attack on Kofuku-ji Temple, Yoshinori tried to drive out Buddhist influence in politics.
sen.cmt: "through military intervention to the"→"with an attack on""political intervention by the Buddhist power"→"Buddhist influence in politics"
sen.e: Also, with an attack on Kofuku-ji Temple, Yoshinori tried to drive out Buddhist influence in politics.

sen.j: 鎌倉公方の足利持氏は自分が僧籍に入っていないことから、義持没後には将軍に就任できると信じており、義教を恨んでいた。
sen.e: A Kamakura Kubo Mochiuji ASHIKAGA had not entered the priesthood; therefore, he believed that he would become a shogun after Yoshimochi's death and this caused him to hate Yoshinori.
Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the Kamakura Kubo, had not entered the priesthood and therefore believed that he would become Shogun after Yoshimochi's death, causing him to hate Yoshinori.
sen.cmt: Moved "Mochiuji ASHIKAGA""a"→"the""; therefore, he"→"and therefore""a shogun"→"Shogun""and this caused "→", causing"
sen.e: Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the Kamakura Kubo, had not entered the priesthood and therefore believed that he would become Shogun after Yoshimochi's death, causing him to hate Yoshinori.

sen.j: 先の年号問題は持氏の妥協でケリが付いたものの、比叡山の呪詛問題、それに1438年（永享10年）には嫡子の元服の際に義教を無視し勝手に名前をつけた（当時は慣例として将軍から一字を拝領していた）ことなどから幕府との関係は一触即発となっていた。
sen.e: The era issue mentioned above was resolved owing to the compromise by Mochiuji; however, the relationship between Yoshinori and the government was at a flash point because the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple cursed him, and also, in 1438, Mochiuji ignored Yoshinori and gave his own son a name when he reached adulthood (according to the custom of that time, one of the Chinese characters used in the shogun's name was given).

The era issue mentioned above was resolved owing to a compromise by Mochiuji but his relationship with the the government remained volatile because of the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple curse issue, and also because, in 1438, Mochiuji ignored Yoshinori and named his son himself when he reached adulthood (according to the custom of that time, one of the Chinese characters used in the shogun's name was given).
sen.cmt: "; however, the relationship between Yoshinori and"→"but his relationship with the""was at a flash point"→"remained volatile""the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple cursed him"→"of the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple curse issue"Added "because""gave his own son a name"→"named his son himself"
sen.e: The era issue mentioned above was resolved owing to a compromise by Mochiuji but his relationship with the the government remained volatile because of the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple curse issue, and also because, in 1438, Mochiuji ignored Yoshinori and named his son himself when he reached adulthood (according to the custom of that time, one of the Chinese characters used in the shogun's name was given).

sen.j: そんな時にたびたび持氏を諌めていた関東管領上杉憲実が疎まれたことにより身の危険を感じて領国の上野に逃亡し、持氏の討伐を受けるに至る。
sen.e: Meanwhile, a Kanto kanrei Norizane UESUGI, who often complained about Mochiuji, felt that his life was in danger as he was clearly disfavored by Mochiuji, and he therefore escaped to one of his territories Kozuke but he was subjugated by Mochiuji there.

Meanwhile, the Kanto Kanrei, Norizane UESUGI, who had often complained about Mochiuji, felt that his life was in danger as he was clearly disfavored by Mochiuji, and he therefore fled to his domain of Kozuke, where he was defeated by Mochiuji.
sen.cmt: "a Kanto kanrei"→"the Kanto Kanrei,""escaped"→"fled""one of his territories"→"his domain of""but he was subjugated by Mochiuji there"→", where he was defeated by Mochiuji"
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Kanto Kanrei, Norizane UESUGI, who had often complained about Mochiuji, felt that his life was in danger as he was clearly disfavored by Mochiuji, and he therefore fled to his domain of Kozuke, where he was defeated by Mochiuji.

sen.j: 義教は好機と見て憲実と結び、関東の諸大名に持氏包囲網を結成させ、持氏討伐の勅令を奉じて朝敵に認定し、1439年（永享11年）に関東討伐に至った（永享の乱）。
sen.e: Yoshinori, seeing an opportunity in this event, made a connection with Norizane and ordered daimyos in Kanto to close Mochiuji off from power, officially identified Mochiuji as the Emperor's enemy following the order to subjugate Mochiuji, and carried out the Kanto subjugation in 1439 (Eikyo Rebellion).

Yoshinori, seeing this as an opportunity, joined forces with Norizane, ordered daimyos in Kanto to close Mochiuji off from power, officially identified Mochiuji as the Emperor's enemy following the imperial order to subjugate Mochiuji, and in 1439, took control of the Kanto area (Eikyo Rebellion).
sen.cmt: "an opportunity in this event"→"this as an opportunity""made a connection"→"joined forces""carried out the Kanto subjugation in 1439"→"in 1439, took control of the Kanto area"
sen.e: Yoshinori, seeing this as an opportunity, joined forces with Norizane, ordered daimyos in Kanto to close Mochiuji off from power, officially identified Mochiuji as the Emperor's enemy following the imperial order to subjugate Mochiuji, and in 1439, took control of the Kanto area (Eikyo Rebellion).

sen.j: 持氏は大敗して剃髪、恭順の姿勢を示した。
sen.e: Defeated badly, Mochiuji shaved his head and showed allegiance.
Badly defeated, Mochiuji took the tonsure and adopted a deferential attitude.
sen.cmt: "shaved his head"→"took the tonsure""showed allegiance"→"adopted a deferential attitude"
sen.e: Badly defeated, Mochiuji took the tonsure and adopted a deferential attitude.

sen.j: しかし義教は憲実の助命嘆願にも拘らず持氏一族を殺害した。
sen.e: Despite Norizane's appeal for mercy, Yoshinori killed the whole Mochiuji clan.
Despite Norizane's appeal for mercy, Yoshinori killed Mochiuji's relatives.
Despite Norizane's appeal for mercy, Yoshinori killed Mochiuji's relatives.

sen.j: その後は関東に自己の勢力を広げていくために実子を新しい鎌倉公方として下向させようとしたが、これは上杉氏の反対にあって頓挫している。
sen.e: Afterwards, Yoshinori attempted to send his own child as a new Kamakura Kubo to expand his own power throughout Kanto, but this plan was not completed due to the opposition from the Uesugi family.
Afterwards, Yoshinori attempted to expand his power throughout Kanto by having his own son made Kanto Kubo, but withdrew the plan in the face of opposition from the Uesugi Clan.
sen.cmt: Changed word order and reworded sentence.
sen.e: Afterwards, Yoshinori attempted to expand his power throughout Kanto by having his own son made Kanto Kubo, but withdrew the plan in the face of opposition from the Uesugi Clan.

tit.j: 関東平定と中央集権の実現
tit.e: Restoration of Order in Kanto and Realization of a Centralized Administrative System
Restoration of Order in Kanto and Realization of a Centralized Administrative System
Restoration of Order in Kanto and Realization of a Centralized Administrative System

sen.j: 鎌倉を平定した義教であったが、1440年（永享12年）に逃亡していた持氏の遺児の安王丸・春王丸兄弟が結城氏朝に担がれて叛乱を起こした（結城合戦）。
sen.e: Kamakura was restored to order by Yoshinori, but in 1440, the An'omaru and Shun'omaru brothers, the bereaved children of the refugee Mochiuji, were deceived by Ujitomo YUKI and started an insurrection (Yuki War).
Yoshinori had restored order to Kamakura, but in 1440, An'omaru and Shun'omaru, the bereaved sons of Mochiuji, were deceived by Ujitomo YUKI into starting an insurrection (Yuki War).
sen.cmt: Changed first clause from passive to activeDeleted "the", "brothers""children"→"sons"Deleted "the refugee""and started"→"into starting"
sen.e: Yoshinori had restored order to Kamakura, but in 1440, Anomaru and Shunomaru, the bereaved sons of Mochiuji, were deceived by Ujitomo YUKI into starting an insurrection (Yuki War).

sen.j: 義教は隠居していた憲実に討伐を命ずるも、関東諸将の頑強な反抗に遭い、力攻めから兵糧攻めに切り替え、翌年の1441年（嘉吉元年）4月には鎮圧された。
sen.e: Although Yoshinori ordered retired Norizane to subjugate them, due to strong opposition by warlords of Kanto, Yoshinori changed the plan to starve out the enemy, and as a result, the insurrection was suppressed in April, 1441, which was the following year.

Although Yoshinori ordered the retired Norizane to attack them, due to strong opposition by the warlords of Kanto, he changed the plan to starve them out and as a result, the insurrection was suppressed the following year in April, 1441.
sen.cmt: Added "the""subjugate"→"attack" "Yoshinori"→"he""the enemy"→"them""which was the following year"→"the following year" and moved
sen.e: Although Yoshinori ordered the retired Norizane to attack them, due to strong opposition by the warlords of Kanto, he changed the plan to starve them out and as a result, the insurrection was suppressed the following year in April, 1441.

sen.j: 春王・安王は京への護送途中で斬られた。
sen.e: The An'omaru and Shun'omaru brothers were slain while they were escorted to Kyoto.
The An'omaru and Shun'omaru brothers were slain while they were escorted to Kyoto.
The Anomaru and Shunomaru brothers were slain while they were escorted to Kyoto.

sen.j: また旧南朝 (日本)勢力の北畠氏を討伐し、旧南朝の宮を次々と粛清もしくは出家させていき、後南朝勢力を壊滅させた。
sen.e: Also, he subjugated the Kitabatake family from the old South Court (Japan), and purged imperial family members or made them enter the priesthood one by one to finally eliminate the force of Go-Nancho or the latter South Court.
He also defeated the Kitabatake Clan from the former Southern Court, and purged imperial family members or made them enter the priesthood to finally destroy the influence of the Latter South Court.
sen.cmt: "Also, he subjugated"→"He also defeated" "family"→"Clan""from"→"of""old South"→"former Southern"Deleted "(Japan)" and "one by one""eliminate"→"destroy""force"→"influence"Deleted " of Go-Nancho or"capitalized 'l'"South"→"Southern"
sen.e: He also defeated the Kitabatake Clan from the former Southern Court, and purged imperial family members or made them enter the priesthood to finally destroy the influence of the Latter South Court.

sen.j: こうして室町幕府の頭痛の種はほとんどが消滅した。
sen.e: This is how most of the headaches for the Muromachi shogunate government were eliminated.
As a result, most of the headaches for the Muromachi shogunate government were eliminated.
As a result, most of the headaches for the Muromachi shogunate government were eliminated.

sen.j: また義教は有力守護大名に対して、その家督継承に積極的に干渉することにより、大内持世や赤松貞村などの自身の腹心を当主に推し支配力を強める政策を行った。
sen.e: Yoshinori furthermore implemented measures to increase his dominance over major Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyos by aggressively interfering with their family inheritance issues and by recommending his own trustworthy assistants such as Mochiyo OUCHI and Sadamura AKAMATSU as the heads of these families.

Furthermore, Yoshinori implemented measures to increase his dominance over major Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyos by aggressively interfering in their family inheritance issues and by recommending his own trusted assistants, such as Mochiyo OUCHI and Sadamura AKAMATSU, as the heads of these families.

Furthermore, Yoshinori implemented measures to increase his dominance over major Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyos by aggressively interfering in their family inheritance issues and by recommending his own trusted assistants, such as Mochiyo OUCHI and Sadamura AKAMATSU, as the heads of these families.

sen.j: 意に反する四職一色義貫や伊勢国守護土岐持頼などは粛清した。
sen.e: Meanwhile, he purged those who opposed him such as Yoshinuki ISSHIKI of the Four Houses and Mochiyori TOKI, a Shugo (Military Governor) of the Province of Ise.

Meanwhile, he purged those who opposed him, such as Yoshinuki ISSHIKI of one of the Four Houses of the Samurai-dokoro administative office and Mochiyori TOKI, a Shugo (Military Governor) of the Province of Ise.
sen.cmt: Added commaAdded "one of"Added explanation of "四職""a"→"the"
sen.e: Meanwhile, he purged those who opposed him, such as Yoshinuki ISSHIKI of Shishiki (Four major feudal lords who worked for Muromachi bakufu) and Mochiyori TOKI, a Shugo (Military Governor) of the Province of Ise.
sen.cmt: 四職→Shishiki (Four major feudal lords who worked for Muromachi bakufu)

sen.j: 九州平定、宗教勢力の押え込み、南朝押え込み、関東平定、守護大名押さえ込みを悉く成し遂げた義教は遂に権力の一元化に成功した。
sen.e: Having restored order in Kyushu, suppressed the religionist force, suppressed the South Court, restored order in Kanto, and suppressed Shugo Daimyos, Yoshinori finally succeeded in centralization of power.
Having restored order in Kyushu, suppressed the religious influence, the Southern Court and the Shugo Daimyos and restored order in Kanto, Yoshinori finally succeeded in centralizing power.
sen.cmt: "religionist force"→"religious influence""South"→"Southern"Added "the""centralization"→"centralizing"Deleted "of"Changed word order to prevent repetition of "suppressed"
sen.e: Having restored order in Kyushu, suppressed the religious influence, the Southern Court and the Shugo Daimyos and restored order in Kanto, Yoshinori finally succeeded in centralizing power.

sen.j: 義教の時代には正長の土一揆や後南朝勢力の反乱など、室町幕府を巡る政治・社会情勢が不穏であり、強力な指導力を持つ将軍の存在が望まれていた武家社会や民衆の要請に沿う形で、義教は幕府権力の強化に一定の成果をあげた。
sen.e: During the time of Yoshinori, both the political and social conditions associated with the Muromachi shogunate government were unsettled as seen in the occurrence of the peasant uprising of Shocho or the rebellion of the Go-Nancho force, and Yoshinori therefore contributed to reinforcement of government power by meeting the needs of the warrior class and the general public for the presence of a shogun with strong leadership.

Both the political and social conditions associated with the Muromachi shogunate government during Yoshinori's time were unsettled, as seen in events such as the Shocho peasant uprising and the rebellion by forces of the Latter Southern Court, and by reinforcing the shogunate's authority, Yoshinori was meeting the needs of the warrior class and the general public for the presence of a shogun with strong leadership.

Both the political and social conditions associated with the Muromachi shogunate government during Yoshinori's time were unsettled, as seen in events such as the Shocho peasant uprising and the rebellion by forces of the Latter Southern Court, and by reinforcing the shogunate's authority, Yoshinori was meeting the needs of the warrior class and the general public for the presence of a shogun with strong leadership.

sen.j: 「万人恐怖」
sen.e: 'Everyone Fears'
'Everyone Fears'
'Everyone Fears'

sen.j: 義教は苛烈な側面を有していた。
sen.e: Yoshinori was said to be sometimes relentless.
Yoshinori was said to be sometimes relentless.
Yoshinori was said to be sometimes relentless.

sen.j: 上記の一色・土岐を暗殺した事や、比叡山の宗徒を殺しまたは焼身自殺させた事の他、権中納言・日野義資を暗殺したと思しき事、皇族・公卿ら数十人を処罰した事、「献上された梅の枝が折れた」「料理がまずい」といった些細な理由で庭師や料理人を罰した事などが『満済准后日記』『看聞日記』『薩戒記』など当時の記録にみえる。
sen.e: Records made at that time such as the 'Mansai Junko Diary,' 'Kammon Diary,' and 'Sakkai-Ki' mentioned that he assassinated ISSHIKI and TOKI as described above, killed Buddhists at the Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple or made them immolate themselves, supposedly assassinated gon-chunagon Yoshisuke HINO, a junior deputy chief of the state counselor, punished dozens of members of the Imperial Family and court aristocracy, and punished gardeners and cooks for the smallest things such as 'a branch of the plum tree received as a gift broke' and 'the food did not taste good.'

Records made at that time, such as the 'Mansai Junko Diary,' 'Kammon Diary,' and 'Sakkai-Ki' mention that, as well as the assassinations of ISSHIKI and TOKI and the killing and forced self-immolation of monks at Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple described above, he also supposedly assassinated Gon-Chunagon (Middle Counselor) Yoshisuke HINO, punished dozens of members of the Imperial Family and court aristocracy, and punished gardeners and cooks for trivial reasons, such as 'a branch of the plum tree received as a gift broke' and 'the food did not taste good.'
sen.cmt: "mentioned"→"mention"Reworded middle part of sentence due to slight mistranslation""a junior deputy chief of the state counselor"→"(Middle Counselo)" and moved"the smallest things"→"trivial reasons"
sen.e: Records made at that time, such as the "Mansai Junko Diary," "Kanmon Diary," and "Sakkai-Ki" mention that, as well as the assassinations of Isshiki and Toki and the killing and forced self-immolation of monks at Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple described above, he also supposedly assassinated Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) Yoshisuke HINO, punished dozens of members of the Imperial Family and court aristocracy, and punished gardeners and cooks for trivial reasons, such as 'a branch of the plum tree received as a gift broke' and 'the food did not taste good.'
sen.cmt: 原文の『』に合わせ'を"にISSHIKI→IsshikiTOKI→Tokiスペース削除権中納言→Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor)‘→'Kammon →Kanmon に変更しました。

sen.j: これらの事跡は義教が恐怖政治を志向した事や、嗜虐性を有していた事を示す逸話として伝えられた。
sen.e: These episodes were passed down as anecdotes showing that Yoshinori aspired to a reign of terror and that he was sadistic.
These episodes were passed down as anecdotes showing that Yoshinori was sadistic and aimed to rule by terror.
sen.cmt: "aspired to a reign of terror"→"aimed to rule by terror"Moved "sadistic
sen.e: These episodes were passed down as anecdotes showing that Yoshinori was sadistic and aimed to rule by terror.

sen.j: 伏見宮貞成親王は『看聞日記』で、比叡山の事件を噂した茶商人が即座に斬首された事につき「万人恐怖シ、言フ莫レ、言フ莫レ」（『看聞日記』永享七年2月8日_(旧暦)条）と評している。
sen.e: Prince Fushiminomiya Sadanari in his 'Kammon Diary' commented on the incident in which a tea merchant who talked about the Hieizan incident was beheaded on the spot saying 'Everyone fears, say nothing, say nothing' (from the 'Kammon Diary' on February 8, 1435).

Prince Fushiminomiya Sadanari in his 'Kammon Diary' commented on an incident in which a tea merchant who talked about the Hieizan incident was beheaded on the spot, saying 'Everyone fears, say nothing, say nothing' (from the 'Kammon Diary' entry of February 8, 1435).

Prince Fushiminomiya Sadanari in his "Kammon Diary" commented on an incident in which a tea merchant who talked about the Hieizan incident was beheaded on the spot, saying 'Everyone fears, say nothing, say nothing' (from the "Kammon Diary" entry of February 8, 1435).

sen.j: 1441年（永享13年）1月に義教は畠山家の家督を、畠山持国から畠山持永に委譲させた。
sen.e: In January, 1441, Yoshinori transferred responsibility for the Hatakeyama family from Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA to Mochinaga HATAKEYAMA.
In January, 1441, Yoshinori transferred responsibility for the Hatakeyama family from Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA to Mochinaga HATAKEYAMA.
In February, 1441, Yoshinori transferred responsibility for the Hatakeyama family from Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA to Mochinaga HATAKEYAMA.

sen.j: ここにいたり赤松満祐・赤松教康父子は追い詰められて義教謀殺を計画した。
sen.e: Brought to the point of despair by the situation, the Akamatsu father and son, Mitsusuke and Noriyasu AKAMATSU, planned to murder Yoshinori.
Having had enough of Yoshinori's dictatorial ways, Mitsusuke AKAMATSU and his son, Noriyasu AKAMATSU, planned to murder him.

sen.e: Having had enough of Yoshinori's dictatorial ways, Mitsusuke AKAMATSU and his son, Noriyasu AKAMATSU, planned to murder him.

sen.j: 同年（改元により嘉吉元年）6月24日、結城合戦戦勝祝宴を名目に義教を自邸に招いた。
sen.e: On June 24, 1441, they invited Yoshinori to their own house in the name of a feast celebrating the victory of the Yuki War.
On June 24, 1441, they invited Yoshinori to their house on the pretext of celebrating victory of the Yuki War.
sen.cmt: Deleted "own""in the name of a feast"→"on the pretext of"Deleted "the" "of"→"in"
sen.e: On July 21, 1441, they invited Yoshinori to their house on the pretext of celebrating victory of the Yuki War.

sen.j: このころ多くの大名家・公家が義教を招いて戦勝祝宴を催していた。
sen.e: Around that time, many daimyo and kuge houses invited Yoshinori to celebrate the victory.
Around that time, many daimyo and kuge (nobles) invited Yoshinori to celebrate the victory.
Around that time, many daimyo and kuge (nobles) invited Yoshinori to celebrate the victory.

sen.j: 義教は赤松氏との和平も兼ねて少数の側近を伴って赤松邸に出かけたが、祝宴の最中に暗殺された。
sen.e: Yoshinori went to the Akamatsu residence with a few guards for the feast and also to take this opportunity to make peace with the Akamatsu family, but he was assassinated during the feast.
Seeing this as an opportunity to make peace with the Akamatsu Clan, Yoshinori went to the Akamatsu residence with a few guards, but was assassinated during the feast.

sen.e: Seeing this as an opportunity to make peace with the Akamatsu Clan, Yoshinori went to the Akamatsu residence with a few guards, but was assassinated during the feast.

sen.j: 主を失った幕府は混乱し討手を差し向けることもなく、満祐・ 教康父子は播磨に帰国するが、同年7月11日、細川持常・山名宗全に追討されて赤松氏は滅亡する（その後、禁闕の変の功で再興）。
sen.e: Losing its leader, the government fell into so much confusion that it did not send any troops, and Mitsusuke and Noriyasu AKAMATSU were able to return to the Province of Harima, however on July 11, 1441, the Akamatsu family was destroyed as they were sought out and killed by Mochitsune HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA (the Akamatsu family later on re-built itself after the Kinketsu Incident).

With the loss of its leader, the government fell into such confusion that it did not send any troops, and Mitsusuke and Noriyasu AKAMATSU were able to return to the Province of Harima but on July 11, 1441, the Akamatsu family was destroyed after being sought out and killed by Mochitsune HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA (the Akamatsu family later on re-built itself after the Kinketsu Incident).
sen.cmt: "Losing"→"With the loss of""so much"→"such""however"→"but""as they were"→"after being"
sen.e: With the loss of its leader, the government fell into such confusion that it did not send any troops, and Mitsusuke and Noriyasu AKAMATSU were able to return to the Province of Harima but on August 6, 1441, the Akamatsu family was destroyed after being sought out and killed by Mochitsune HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA (the Akamatsu family later on re-built itself after the Kinketsu Incident).

sen.j: これを嘉吉の乱という。
sen.e: This was the Kakitsu Incident.
His assassination is known as the Kakitsu Incident.

sen.j: 貞成親王は「将軍此ノ如キ犬死ニハ古来ソノ例ヲ聞カザル事ナリ」（『看聞日記』）と評した。
sen.e: Prince Sadanari in his 'Kammon Diary' commented on this incident saying 'There had not been any shoguns before who died so wastefully' (from the 'Kammon Diary').
Prince Sadanari in his 'Kammon Diary' commented on this incident saying 'Never has a shogun died so wastefully'.
sen.cmt: "here had not been any shoguns before who"→"Never has a shogun"Deleted "(from the ‘Kammon Diary’)"
sen.e: Prince Sadanari in his "Kammon Diary" commented on this incident saying 'Never has a shogun died so wastefully.'

sen.j: この結果、義教によって復興された権力はこの後弱体化していくが、義政の東山文化を支えた将軍の中央集権権力は、義教の代に再び確立されたことも事実である。
sen.e: As a result, the power that was once restored by Yoshinori became weaker, but it is still true that the centralized administrative power of the shogun that supported the Higashiyama culture led by Yoshimasa was re-built during Yoshinori's generation.

As a result, the authority that Yoshinori had restored became weaker, but it remains a fact that the centralized authoritarian power of the shogun that supported the Higashiyama culture, led by Yoshinori's son, Yoshimasa, was re-built during Yoshinori's time.
sen.cmt: "power that was once restored by Yoshinori"→"the authority that Yoshinori had restored""is still true"→"remains a fact""administrative"→"authoritarian"Added "Yoshinori's son" for clarification"generation"→"time"
sen.e: As a result, the authority that Yoshinori had restored became weaker, but it remains a fact that the centralized authoritarian power of the shogun that supported the Higashiyama culture, led by Yoshinori's son, Yoshimasa, was re-built during Yoshinori's time.

sen.j: また義教の設立した奉公衆制度は将軍権力を支え、応仁の乱を経て明応の政変まで将軍権力を維持していくことになる。
sen.e: Also, the guard force system that Yoshinori established supported the power of the shogun and maintained it until the Meio Political Change after the Onin War.
Also, the Hokoshu that Yoshinori established supported and maintained the authority of the shogun until the Meio Coup after the Onin War.

sen.j: 1428年（応永35）3月12日、従五位下に叙し、左馬頭に任官。
sen.e: On March 12, 1428, he was given the Junior Fifth Court Rank and was appointed to the Samanokami/Hidarino-umanokami, which was the Minister of the Horse Office of the Left.
On March 12, 1428, he was given the Junior Fifth, Lower Grade Court Rank and was appointed Samanokami, or Head of the Imperial Stables of the Left.
sen.cmt: Added "Lower Grade"Deleted "to the""/Hidarino-umanokami, which was the Minister of the Horse Office of the Left"→"Head of the Imperial Stables of the Left"

sen.cmt: 従五位下→Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)左馬頭→Sama no kami (Captain of Samaryo, Left Division of Bureau of Horses)On March 12, 1428, he→March 12, 1428: Heに変更しました。

sen.j: 還俗し義宣と名のる。
sen.e: He then returned to secular life and named himself Yoshinobu.

sen.j: 4月14日、従四位下に昇叙。
sen.e: On April 14, he was promoted to the Lower Junior Fourth Rank.
On April 14, he was promoted to the Junior Fourth, Lower Grade Rank.
On April 14, he was promoted to the Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 従四位下→Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade)

sen.e: On March 9, 1429, he came to the age of maturity.

sen.cmt: On March 9, 1429, he→March 9, 1429: Heに変更しました。

sen.j: 3月15日、参議に補任し、左近衛中将を兼任、征夷大将軍宣下。
sen.e: On March 15th, he was appointed to Sangi or Councilor, was also appointed to Sakon'eno-chujyo or Deputy General of Imperial Guard of the Left, and received an imperial proclamation to appoint him to Seii Taishogun, which was a Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo.
On March 15th, he was made a Sangi or Councilor, was also appointed Sakon'eno-chujyo, or Deputy General of the Imperial Guards of the Left, and was named Seii Taishogun by imperial proclamation.
sen.cmt: "appointed to"→"made a"Deleted "to"Added "the" and 's'"received an imperial proclamation to appoint him to"→"was named…by imperial proclamation"Deleted "which was a Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo"
sen.e: On March 15th, he was made a Sangi (councillor), was also appointed Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards), and was named Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") by imperial proclamation.
sen.cmt: 参議→Sangi (councillor)左近衛中将→Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards)征夷大将軍→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")

sen.j: 義教に改名。
sen.e: He changed his name to Yoshinori.

sen.j: 3月29日、従三位に昇叙し、権大納言に転任。
sen.e: On March 29, he was promoted to the Junior Third Court Rank and then was reassigned to Gon-Dainagon or Junior Chief of the Councilor of State.
